discourse_list.title: Proposal Idea - Purchase ETH for Strategic Reserves [Poll]

content.content: All, Following the Oracle team’s gas budget request, I would like to discuss a proposal to purchase additional ETH held by the protocol as strategic reserves to hedge any sustained spikes in ETH price and Gwei. I performed a simple linear extrapolation of the prior six weeks of actual average Gwei per day through Q1 2023 (directly below) and put in some different ETH price points to estimate the $ impact on our oracle costs (bottom table). To be clear - this extrapolation is not my forecast, there are a number of factors which put downward pressure on Gwei. The data is simply to illustrate how quickly costs can increase even with somewhat modest increases in ETH price and Gwei.  1679×676 17.3 KB   782×167 9.72 KB  As you can see from the above, if ETH hits $15K by the end of Q1 and Gwei increases by 80% from 149 to 268 per day, we could see gas costs balloon by nearly 10x. We have seen multiple occasions over ETH’s history and even this past year of it’s price doubling within six weeks. As we’re all aware, crypto markets can move quite quickly and without warning. Having an additional backstop of ETH in reserves will provide us with a larger safety net and could save tens of millions of dollars of funds. If sustained increases in Gwei or ETH do not materialize, the DAO can decide whether to sell a portion of the ETH or continue to hold in reserves. To be clear, this proposal is supplementary to the funds the Oracles Core Unit requested for Q1 and for emergencies. If the Oracle gas budget is exhausted prior to the end of any quarter, the Oracle team can request ETH from the strategic reserve. This Strategic Reserve could also be accessed by the PE team for smart contract deployments and testing. Pros  Hedges and mitigates higher oracle expenses due to sustained Gwei and ETH price appreciation Provides price exposure to increases in ETH price (which as we’re aware has outperformed MKR)  Cons  Increases bad debt risk by having non-stable assets in the Surplus Buffer  Note - analysis assumes the same number of Oracles are active as were in October which will likely overestimate Oracle gas expenses as multiple collaterals are in the process of being offboarded.  How Much? Regarding the amount to be purchased, our initial recommendation is for 2,000 ETH, currently valued at $9,000,000. This is a little over 7 months of gas supply at current ETH & Gwei, and 4 months of supply at $15K ETH and 268 Gwei. Would really like to get community input on this number and the proposal in general. Longer term we will want to refine this number but today we are limited by the Surplus Buffer, which currently sits at $60M and will decrease by $8.8M once the Oracle gas budget is passed.  How to Implement? I have already brought up the idea with @Derek and he has started discussing with the PE team. If the DAO decides we should pursue this path, I believe the team will be able to write up a requirement doc and technical implementation.    Should the DAO purchase ETH as Strategic Reserves to Hedge Gas Costs?  Yes No Abstain     0 voters        How much ETH (in DAI Terms) should be purchased for reserves?  3M 6M 9M 12M None Other Abstain     0 voters

content.content: My first question would be how this proposal relates to the surplus buffer? As far as I can tell this will directly remove funds from the surplus buffer and with it further postpone burning and worsening our ratio of surplus to non-stablecoin. 9M at current rates will take a month and a half to get back. As for the need of this strategic reserve; In a scenario with rising ETH price we are most likely also increasing revenue and should thus be naturally hedged. In a scenario of rapid market downturn we are likely to see an increase in gwei cost but a reduction in ETH price. This is where we expects the numbers of liquidations to increase and if worst comes to worst have to dip into the surplus buffer. On a political level this proposal seems to undermine the compromise that was reached in the big debate surrounding the surplus buffer. That is unfortunate and feeds into the narrative that Maker DAO doesn’t really have any intention of ever burning any MKR. The logical response to constant proposals to either rise the surplus buffer or drain from it would be to start a similar vein of proposals to reduce the surplus buffer and I think we can all agree that would be very unproductive.

content.content: In addition to plotting historical correlations between ETH price, oracle expenses, and Maker operating income, we should also include comparison of ETH price vs VaR (value at risk from vaults). I suspect that ETH price and VaR are positively correlated - as ETH price rises, the volume of non-stablecoin risky debt increases which increases potential amount of losses during a market crash. So separately from holding ETH to hedge oracle and contract deployment costs, it could also make sense to allocate some of the reserves to ETH to help maintain surplus buffer to non-stablecoin debt ratios during bull runs. We would need to systematically take profit on the way up to save stable reserves for price crashes - this could be accomplished through investing in an AMM pool (eg UNIV2DAIETH), or using an index fund style rebalancing mechanism based on fixed periods or maximum variance versus a target allocation.

content.content: rune:  I voted no because I believe that gas and eth price aren’t necessarily linked, and gas is more related to the economic activity happening on chain. So while I like the idea of acquiring ETH I’m just not sure that gas expenses are a good justification for it, but like others are saying, if we can show that it does matter and it is a good form of hedging costs then I’m all for it.   Thanks for the comments Rune. I did not mean to imply that ETH price and Gwei were correlated, though I can see how that could be viewed as implicit from the table I posted - Gwei could spike up or down regardless of ETH price due to demand for on chain transactions as you mention. The point I was trying to make with that data set was that an increase in both ETH and Gwei simultaneously exponentially increases our oracle gas costs which may not be intuitive to those less familiar with the economics of oracles. While the motivation for the proposal was my concern with oracle costs, there are strong benefits to holding ETH outright in the form of staked ETH or through an AMM LP as it is a productive asset. I’m also strongly in favor of the protocol providing AMM LPs as you mention and believe @MakerMan is working on a proposal to do just that. Purchasing ETH or stETH could be the first step in pursuing that path. Circling back to my motivation for hedging these costs - what I see looking at the L1 landscape is:  Strong momentum in unique wallet creation Network transactions increasing More and more dev activity, projects, and integrations built on ETH An increasing amount of ETH being locked in smart contracts supply of ETH on exchange at 3 year lows Over 50% of ETH supply hasn’t moved in >1 year an NFT boom using the more gas intensive ERC-721 standard  On top of that, the merge is likely to take place by the end of Q1 2022 and will likely reduce new supply by a factor of 10 and make the ETH protocol net deflationary. With the merge, staking ETH will be made available to all users and the APY will increase from the ETH 2.0 smart contract due to transaction fees going to validators. I believe we will see a significant portion of ETH supply vacuumed into staking contracts dramatically reducing circulating ETH supply. These market dynamics could lead to a scenario where both ETH price and Gwei simultaneously increase and our oracle gas costs explode. If we happen to lose market share (due to LM incentives offered elsewhere or other competitive pressures) we could be in a situation where the increase in revenue (if any) does not offset the increase in oracle costs and we suffer significant margin compression. We could take a band aid approach and offboard most non-ETH and WBTC collaterals but that is not in the best interest of MakerDAO’s users. There seems to be a general overconfidence that we will maintain ETH market share indefinitely. Perhaps that will happen and maybe that’s even the most likely outcome, but we should be hoping for the best and planning for the worst case scenarios. Today we still have extremely high concentration risk amongst borrowers which could exacerbate any shifts in market share. I hope like hell that L2s explode and take some of the strain off of L1 - but we cannot plan for this just like the world cannot plan for someone to save the world from climate change. Actions must be taken. Perhaps I’m wrong about all of this and we’re on the precipice of another multi-year bear market. However if there’s a chance I’m right, even if it’s small, I believe we should hedge at least a portion of our exposure. Thank you for coming to my Ted Talk.

content.content: This is a very complicated topic indeed. Starting from first principles, we can control some of the complexity. The problem at hand revolves around two principles.  Transaction demand:  Given low enough gas price, the demand for on-chain compute is unlimited.  Gas price:  Gas price is no thing other than the price at which the participants in the Ethereum Blockchain marketplace are willing to exchange ETH for on-chain compute at a given point in time. If we want to understand what drives the price of gas, then we need to look at which activities are occupying the largest share of the limited on chain compute. Does a contraction in ETH supply growth due to ETH2.0 merge increase the price at which the participants in the Ethereum Blockchain marketplace are willing to exchange ETH for on-chain compute? Is this equation altered if the price of 1 ETH is 2000 Dai as opposed to 10,000 Dai? By themselves, these variables do not alter the gas price equation. I conjecture that rather than gas price being causally correlated with ETH price, gas spikes are more directly affected by ETH price momentum, or with price momentum of other on-chain assets, such as NFTs, liquidity pools, or maker vaults. For this reason, gas price is likely to go up when the price of ETH goes up rapidly, but also when the price of ETH goes down rapidly. Absent this volatility, gas price will be determined by organic demand for on chain transactions. It will be natural for organic demand for on chain compute to increase over time. However, compute supply will also significantly increase in the near to mid term due to sharding. This may provide temporary easing to compute demand pressure. Because demand for free on chain compute is unlimited, we cannot expect sharding to decrease gas costs linearly with respect to capacity increase. Instead, I conjecture that it will be a logarithmic relation. This leaves L2 scaling as the only hope for a permanent solution to the problem. This however, is not guaranteed. We have thus identified future gas cost as a material risk for MakerDAO’s investors. It is therefore very important to have foresight when it comes to the handling of gas costs required for the continued operation of MakerDAO’s on-chain compute. At the moment, the largest cost is associated with the operation of Oracles. Let’s enumerate possible strategies for mitigating risk associated with increasing gas costs:  Increase earnings by acquiring more vault customers. Carefully evaluate opportunity cost of on-boarding and off-boarding collateral types. Develop more gas-efficient protocols for our on-chain compute. Offload on-chain compute into L2. Opportunistically allocate surplus capital to an ETH reserve in order to hedge.  Each and every one of these strategies should be evaluated and pursued simultaneously. Each represents unique challenges and opportunities. Hedging represents a specially complex challenge because unlike with the other 4 strategies, it is hard to determine a priori whether or not a course of action will be successful. For this reason, I want to emphasize that hedging should be inherently opportunistic in the sense that it must be pondered against opportunity cost, and executed only if the market provides a clear and evident opportunity to do. Opportunity cost will not be easy to determine, because hedging against future gas cost by exchanging Dai for ETH depends at the very least on the future values of:  USD (Dai) MKR ETH Gwei base fees  Therefore, depending on the scenario, opportunity cost will be governed by a combination of these factors. For instance:   Market flash crash scenario - Price of ETH vs Dai collapses, but the product of ETH price * GWEI base fee spikes with respect to Dai. Cheap ETH but expensive gas. This means our hedge fails because purchasing ETH just-in-time will outperform the anticipated hedge.   Parabolic bull run scenario - Price of ETH vs Dai skyrockets, and gwei base fee spikes. Expensive ETH, very expensive gas. This means our hedge will be profitable, as we will avoid consuming the supply buffer at a time when ETH price is higher.   However, in both scenarios you have to compare the opportunity cost of ETH vs MKR. Remember that the purpose of the supply buffer is first and foremost to prevent bad debt from causing us to mint MKR, but beyond that, it allows the DAO to return material value back to holders by repurchasing and burning MKR. This means that for our hedge to be profitable, ETH must outperform not only the Dai, but also MKR. Because the intrinsic value of ETH is much harder to estimate than the intrinsic value of MKR, it seems very speculative to allocate capital to ETH when MKR looks undervalued. Hedging in such a situation would mean choosing a less certain opportunity over a more certain one. If we are to allocate surplus funds to an ETH reserve, it would be wisest to do so at a time when ETH has been in a downtrend for a significant period of time, and at the same time MKR appears relatively expensive. And if we are to spend those funds in the ETH reserve to cover gas costs, it should be done at a time when Gwei base fees are greatly overpriced in terms of Dai relative to the baseline, and ETH is significantly more expensive than the price at which it was purchased. Whether or not such conditions will ever be met, and whether or not we will be able to recognize and act on such opportunities is very hard to forecast. In any case, the surplus buffer should not contain volatile assets. ETH reserves if any, should be held in a treasury instead. The surplus buffer needs to be stable in order to pay out CU salaries and other expenses, and in order for bad debt risk to be managed properly. We don’t want to spend our ETH reserves in order to cover bad debt because liquidations happen at times when ETH price has downward momentum. I do like the idea of using profits from ETH vault liquidations in order to accumulate ETH over time, as this requires little governance overhead and is inherently opportunistic. It would be very interesting to do a back-test and check whether or not this could have been enough to cover oracle gas costs in the past.
